channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Daughter of Jailed Ex-Leader in Ukraine Urges Pardon
item.description: The daughter of former Prime Minister Yulia A. Tymoshenko is seeking freedom for her mother and seeing an example in the release of Russia’s best-known political prisoner.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE and ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: The Caucus: Live Coverage of Obama’s News Conference
item.description: President Obama spoke about the N.S.A., health law signups and the ambitions of his second term.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: President Obama arrived in the White House briefing room on Friday for his year-end news conference.

item.title: Nigella Lawson Assistants Found Not Guilty of Fraud
item.description: Two Italians sisters who spent more than a million dollars on the celebrity chef Nigella Lawson’s credit cards were acquitted of fraud charges by a London jury.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: London Theaters Checked After Ceiling Collapse
item.description: The authorities were carrying out inspections as a precaution, a day after part of a ceiling fell at the Apollo Theater, injuring 87 people.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: The Apollo Theater, on Shaftesbury Avenue, opened in London in 1901.

item.title: The Lede: Statement From Khodorkovsky in Berlin
item.description: Hours after his sudden release from prison on Friday, the Russian dissident Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky released a statement from Berlin, along with an image of himself free for the first time in 10 years.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: Mikhail Khodorkovsky, at left, shaking hands with the former German foreign minister, Hans-Dietrich Genscher, at the airport in Berlin on Friday.

item.title: Ugandan Parliament Approves Antigay Law
item.description: The effort to introduce harsher punishments included life imprisonment for what the law called “aggravated homosexuality,” news reports said.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Refugee Crisis Worsens in Central African Republic, U.N. Agencies Report
item.description: Sectarian violence has driven more than 700,000 from their homes and pushed tens of thousands more into neighboring countries as attacks and reprisals spread, groups say.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: South Africa’s Biggest Union Pulls Support for A.N.C.
item.description: The move is likely to erode the dominance of the African National Congress ahead of elections and reorder the politics of a country it has governed with huge majorities since the end of white rule.
item.dc:creator: By LYDIA POLGREEN

item.title: Freed Abruptly by Putin, Tycoon Arrives in Germany
item.description: Mikhail Khodorkovsky, once Russia’s richest man, flew to Berlin on a private jet after President Vladimir V. Putin signed a decree pardoning him early Friday.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN LEE MYERS and DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: Mikhail Khodorkovsky, left, shook hands with Hans-Dietrich Genscher, former German foreign minister, in Berlin on Friday.

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: December 20
item.description: After getting the Initial Operational Clearance, the aircraft moved a step closer to be inducted into the squadrons of the Indian Air Force.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Tejas, India's indigenously developed supersonic fighter aircraft, taking off at the Hindustan Aeronautics Limited airport in Bangalore, Karnataka.

item.title: India Ink: Report Card Ranks Lower House of Parliament as Least Productive Ever
item.description: PRS Legislative Research, an independent research house in New Delhi, found the 15th Lok Sabha falls short compared to its predecessors.
item.dc:creator: By HARI KUMAR
item.media:description: A view of the Parliament building in New Delhi on Tuesday.

item.title: N.S.A. Dragnet Included Allies, Aid Groups and Business Elite
item.description: Documents leaked by Edward J. Snowden reveal that an Israeli prime minister and the heads of international aid organizations were among more than 1,000 subjects of surveillance in recent years.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES GLANZ and ANDREW W. LEHREN

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China Targets Lavish Funerals in Crackdown on Official Corruption
item.description: As part of efforts to curb official extravagance, the Communist Party has called for curbs on expensive funeral rites for dead officials and their relatives.
item.dc:creator: By AMY QIN
item.media:description: A limousine carrying the coffin of a Jiangsu Province village chief in March. The Communist Party has directed members not to hold lavish funerals as part of a larger campaign against corruption and extravagance.

item.title: India Ink: Christie’s First Auction in India Breaks Records for Local Artists
item.description: The sale brought in $15.4 million, almost double Christie’s high estimate of $8 million, demonstrating robust demand in the Indian art market.
item.dc:creator: By GAYATRI RANGACHARI SHAH
item.media:description: An untitled artwork by Vasudeo S. Gaitonde.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese Navy to Aid U.S. Ship Destroying Syrian Chemical Weapons
item.description: Amid continuing territorial tensions in the South China Sea, analysts are hailing China’s decision to aid an American ship tasked with destroying chemical weapons from Syria as a gesture of cooperation.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ
item.media:description: The move is seen as a wish by China to cooperate in an important international operation.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Carp ‘Saved,’ Then Caught, as Religious Act Goes Awry in China
item.description: In a religious ritual gone awry, 800 carp released into the Yellow River in China’s Shandong Province attracted a group of fishermen downstream who threw large nets to haul them out again, state media reported.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: Drive for Syrian Peace Talks Resumes in Geneva
item.description: Senior diplomats from the United Nations, the United States and Russia work to convene a second international conference.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Growing Corruption Inquiry Hits Close to Turkish Leader
item.description: Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan weathered a summer of protest, but a corruption scandal poses a greater challenge.
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO, SEBNEM ARSU and CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: Mayor and 3 Others Shot Outside Philippine Airport
item.description: Motorcycle-riding gunmen fatally shot four people in front of the Manila airport, sending blood-splattered holiday travelers fleeing in terror.
item.dc:creator: By FLOYD WHALEY

item.title: U.N. Sends Rescue Helicopters to South Sudan as Crisis Worsens
item.description: The United Nations said it would rescue personnel from a base in Akobo, and Britain said it was sending a second airplane to the capital, Juba, to help its citizens escape.
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL and RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: A man and his son inside a United Nations peacekeeping base on Thursday in Juba, South Sudan, the world’s youngest country.

item.title: Putin Signs Decree Pardoning Jailed Oil Tycoon
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia on Friday signed a decree pardoning jailed tycoon Mikhail Khodorkovsky, the Kremlin said.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN LEE MYERS and DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: Mikhail Khodorkovsky, in court in 2010, was one of Russia’s richest and most powerful men when he was imprisoned in 2003.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese Respondents Top Materialism Poll
item.description: Chinese citizens topped a global poll looking into materialism, with 71 percent of respondents agreeing with the statement “I measure success by the things I own.”
item.dc:creator: By BREE FENG
item.media:description: A woman shops for handbags at a Gucci boutique in Shanghai. China is the world's third-biggest market for personal luxury goods.

item.title: Death of Indonesian Copywriter Brings Scrutiny to Advertising Industry
item.description: Ananda Pradnya Paramita, 27, died shortly after posting on Twitter that she had worked for 30 hours straight, prompting criticism of the industry’s workaholic culture.
item.dc:creator: By KATE LAMB

item.title: India Ink: A Conversation With: Political Scientist Ashutosh Varshney
item.description: Mr. Varshney spoke about the politics of citizenship and the rise of Narendra Modi.
item.dc:creator: By VISHNU VARMA
item.media:credit: Courtesy of Penguin Books India Publicity
item.media:description: Ashutosh Varshney, a professor of political science at Brown University.

item.title: North Korea Warns South of Strikes Amid Turmoil
item.description: The latest threat came amid concerns that the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, might stage an armed provocation to raise tensions to consolidate power.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN
